author: Chris Knight
title: Attention travellers: What is the exchange rate for my summer holiday?
text:

The flights and hotel are booked, the days out are planned and you even know which bars serve the best cocktails on Saturday night. 
All you have left to do ahead of your summer holiday is snap up your euros and dollars before you jet off. 
But when it comes to exchange rates for your summer holiday, how much bang can you expect for your buck? 
The value of sterling dived back in March around the Governmentâ€™s announcement triggering Article 50, but the currency has since bounced back. 
The pound even enjoyed a 10-month high against the US dollar during the recent rounds of Brexit talks. 
In contrast though, the pound continues to struggle in value against the euro, falling by 0.4 per cent on Friday. Read More 
Holidaymakers catching flights at the start of summer holidays risked getting stung at certain airports by dramatically low exchange rates. 
Jetsetters from Gatwick, Luton and Birmingham airports were all offered less than a euro for each pound. 
But for those of you looking to sort out the holiday cash ahead of your flight, what rates can you expect? Read More All areas of North East will be hit by Brexit, new study shows 
According to currency exchange website XE, holidaymakers to the Eurozone should look to get 1.117 euros to the pound. 
Travellers heading stateside will have the benefit of a slightly better rate, with a return of 1.31 dollars to the pound. 
These exchange rates are correct according to website XE as of July 30. Like us on Facebook
